text: the internet's busiest music nerd it's
time for a review of the new Ed Sheeran
album subtract singer songwriter Ed
Sheeran one of the biggest artists out
there in the mainstream surely needs no
introduction at this point he has just
come through with his sixth full-length
LP over here subtract and it's an
interesting shift in the Ed Sheeran
discography for a few reasons I feel
like Ed leading up to this point in his
catalog has been progressively going
poppier and poppier and poppier
especially on records such as divide and
don't get me wrong I mean while I have
not been crazy about this change this
has led to huge streaming numbers and
big big big big big hit songs for Edward
so it is interesting in this long
awaited Edition uh in his series of
Records where you know he's pretty much
like hitting us with uh math equation
science we got multiplying we got
addition and we got divide and we got
equals but no comparatively subtract
over here is not only a record that sees
Ed taking things in a simpler Direction
not piling too much instrumentation on
hence why the subtraction sign makes
sense but thematically there are a lot
of songs here that deal in loss or the
potential loss of romance maybe a
relationship being in a state where
things kind of hang in the balance
there's a lot of questions are are
things going to move forward from here
can we make it past this obstacle can we
make it through this year so I respect
the fact that Ed seemingly took his time
and put a lot of thought into how he
would reach this point in the series and
it's led to some highs however I will
say Ed Sheeran for a lot of reasons has
never been one of my favorite
singer-songwriters of all time and many
of his shortcomings and the basic
artistically basic Tendencies also carry
over onto this project too so I don't
know I'm just kind of at a loss with
this thing a bit torn because while it
does feel like an improvement in some
respects over his those last couple of
LPS and there is a lot of focus going on
throughout the record there are some
things about it at its core I'm not
crazy about and I guess uh let me start
to get into the songs here to kind of
explain as to why from the opening track
Ed's very boyish melodramatic
singer-songwriter style doesn't really
tug at my heartstrings but I can sense
that at least by Ed Sheeran's standards
this particular song in in this record
uh it's kicking things off in a way that
feels raw and very emotionally exposed
for him I'm getting similar Vibes off
the track life goes on as well I can
sense Ed as an artist is attempting to
push some emotional buttons here but at
least for me it just doesn't cut that
deep take the following track saltwater
for example whose instrumentation sounds
like something out of a soundtrack from
a big budget rom-com that has a very mid
score on Rotten Tomatoes so musically
it's not quite there but I will give it
to Ed on the lyrical side of this track
because I think the imagery of being
submerged in water and it being cold
this cold salt water rushing in in a way
and all of it being a part of a dream
certainly is evocative however it
doesn't take long on this record for
some of the instrumentals to get kind of
tacky like in the case of eyes closed
where the basic beats and super heavy
chorus effects on Ed's voice frankly
stank they make Ed's singing sound
really sour and unnecessarily mushy
which is sad because his performance on
this track vocally is actually really
good especially on the chorus as he's
belting out
there probably could have been a dozen
different ways that Ed could have worked
in some beats and some Electronics to
give a song where he's referencing
dancing a bit of a Groove without it
sounding this freaking I guess uh
regimented and plain like the musical
equivalent to some cheesy millennial
Home Goods I don't know like a a plaque
about wine or something I have similar
issues with the tracks Dusty as well as
curtains later on the record we're
obviously Ed and all involved are trying
to bring a bit of a pop or maybe even a
rock flare into the record to give it a
bit of variation some Tempo but honestly
throwing all this extra stuff in just
makes the songs sound milder or just
flavorless like for example the track
Sycamore is so airbrushed and glossed
out I feel like I'm listening to a
completely toothless piece of Christian
rock because you know any textures that
are a bit too rough might inspire a
sinful thought or something in my
opinion it's often the most skeletal
cuts on the record that are the most
emotionally impactful case in point the
song Vega or even end of Youth which not
only works because Ed's vocals and the
pianos on the cut Remain the focal point
of the track no matter what point you're
in but the vocal breaks where you're
singing about it being a long year hit
hard and he's really going off in the
lyrics in this track about hitting some
kind of emotional Rock Bottom the
following colorblind though I thought
was one of a few moments on the record
that just feel instrumentally too plain
and basic and if you don't know what I
mean just listen to the plinky dinky
pianos and strings on this cut it sounds
like something out of a a musical piece
from a YouTube kids channel trying to
get two-year-olds to sleep with a
lullaby like it's really no surprise
that Ed Sheeran routinely finds himself
in these positions where people are
trying to sue him because of the
similarity of his songs to others and
not to say he's uniquely guilty of
anything here but he doesn't dress his
chords up or his instrumentation up in
any way creatively or interestingly
everything just has like the plainest
possible presentation that it could have
and as a result like you can hear so
much Deja Vu musically going on in a lot
of what he does some more details some
nuances some textures really some
anything would help alleviate this but
Ed just continues to show no interest in
it the track spark though I would say is
one of the few instances on this LP
where really piling the instrumentation
on has some pretty positive results
though still the opening piano chords
sound like something McLemore would wrap
over legitimately still once the drums
and strings come in those feel actually
quite a bit more organic than any sets
of drums and strings at any other point
on the project the overly sentimental
lyrics about romantic Sparks do make me
roll my eyes a little bit however there
is kind of this sense of worry
throughout the track about whether or
not this relationship is gonna make it
is it going to survive the spark kind of
building into a fire that's kind of
burning everything there's volatility
there something is at stake and while
rarely are Ed's observations on love and
relationships in this LP the super
profound maybe they don't need to be be
being on the money might just be enough
I suppose because I can't say what Ed is
saying here in terms of like you know
Framing and the general functionality of
love and uh romantic connections is uh
toxic or uh super inaccurate it's really
the lack of specifics and details that
make things difficult to invest in which
is the case for the closing track a very
bulky number in which I do appreciate
the beds of acoustic instrumentation
here but the vocal Harmony still sounds
so artificial the way they're layered up
and touched up still I do think Ed
brings a nice touch with all the Nimble
melodic breaks across the track that are
obviously meant to be a nod to the
region of Scotland that is referenced in
the title but overall I found the track
to be a bit inconclusive as a finisher
maybe in a respect I do understand that
given that it does kind of leave things
off with a cliffhanger it's kind of a
good buy with Ed saying that no heart
will love this person as much as his did
which is a sad sentiment yes but I kind
of leave this track feeling uh not too
many feels because I have more questions
than feels what is this love you're
singing about what is the story behind
it why are we at this place of distance
and impasse why the location I need to
know these things and while I'm sure
there are answers to them uh that uh
maybe some hardcore Ed Sheeran fans are
furiously typing in the comments what
I'm trying to get to here is that Ed
isn't offering a lot of these answers in
the song itself and as a result
um I'm just having a hard time getting
excited about or invested in the song
even if it does sound pretty on the
surface however it is nice to know that
Ed has been kind of playing the long
game with this new record of his because
uh this track from what I understand is
about 10 years old so it's cool to see
him kind of add this song that
contributes to a greater theme across
this record yeah at the end of the day I
wish I was crazy year about this record
I wish I loved it more because I can
recognize that in a way it is better
than some of his recent output but I
still found the tracklist to be kind of

that got me going a little bit

singer-songwriter music that is kind of

heavy potent drama while sure there is a
